nodes.text: Teacher value-added (VA) measures based on impacts on students' test scores predict teachers' long-term effects on students' adult outcomes (college attendance, college quality, earnings, and other social outcomes)
We linked administrative school district records for grades 3–8 (1989–2009) to US federal tax records (1996–2011), matching roughly 90 percent to track about one million students into adulthood

Two empirical designs were used: (A) cross-sectional comparisons across classrooms controlling for rich observables (selection on observables) and (B) a quasi-experimental cohort-differencing design exploiting teacher turnover across adjacent cohorts within school-grade cells

Companion analysis shows the test-score VA estimates (leave-year-out, with lagged scores and controls) are forecast-unbiased and exhibit little bias, justifying use of VA estimates as instruments for true teacher VA
Cross-class comparisons: a one standard deviation increase in teacher VA in a single grade raises college attendance at age 20 by about 0.82 percentage points (mean attendance ~37 percent)

Cross-class comparisons: a one standard deviation increase in teacher VA raises college quality (earnings-based index) by about $299 at age 20 and increases probability of attending a high-quality college and spending four or more years in college

Cross-class comparisons: a one standard deviation increase in teacher VA in a single grade increases annual earnings at age 28 by roughly 1.3–1.65 percent (preferred estimate ~1.34 percent), implying a present value lifetime-earnings gain of about $7,000 per student (discounted) or ~$39,000 undiscounted

Cross-class comparisons: higher teacher VA reduces probability of teenage birth (female) by ~0.61 percentage points, raises neighborhood SES (percent college grads) and increases 401(k) participation at age 28

Teachers' test-score impacts on subsequent-year test scores fade out rapidly (stabilize at ~25 percent after 3–4 years), yet impacts on adult outcomes re-emerge in college and earnings (pattern of fade-out and re-emergence)

Quasi-experimental cohort-switch estimates: changes in mean teacher VA across adjacent cohorts within school-grade explain changes in college attendance (one SD VA raises attendance by ~0.86 pp) and college quality (~$198), supporting causal interpretation and validating cross-class estimates

Policy implication: replacing a teacher in the bottom 5 percent of VA with an average teacher yields large gains; selection on true VA implies ~$407,000 PV per classroom while accounting for drift and feasible estimation yields roughly $185,000–$266,000 per classroom (three-year VA estimate and adjustment)

VA estimation and empirical implementation: leave-year-out VA estimates, scale to SD units by subject and level, control vectors include lagged scores and student/class covariates, standard errors clustered by school-cohort, trim top 1% suspected cheating

Conclusion: test-score-based VA measures are informative proxies for teachers' effects on long-term adult outcomes and could be useful for personnel policies, but use should consider potential behavioral responses and complementarities with other evaluation measures

Limitation: quasi-experimental estimates are underpowered for earnings outcomes due to limited sample of students observed at older ages and limited early teacher data, so earnings causal estimates rely primarily on cross-class design
Identification assumption for cross-class design: selection on observables—conditional on controls and lagged scores, unobserved determinants of adult outcomes are uncorrelated with teacher VA
